column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/baker-mayfield-gets-his-men/|Baker Mayfield Gets His Men|Sage of Tampa Bay Sports Ira Kaufman likes to say one thing in particular about the 2025 edition of Baker Mayfield.  “He’s callin’ a lot of shots at One Buc.” That may be a bit of hyperbole
column2: but there’s plenty of truth to it. Mayfield got his offensive coordinator for the second consecutive season
column3: and he got Chris Godwin back along with today’s news of receiver Sterling Shepard re-signing. And don’t forget Mayfield’s starting line is intact
column4: though key O-line backups and Mayfield friends have left the building Robert Hainsey (Jacksonville) and Justin Skule (Minnesota). Shepard
column6: was Mayfield’s college teammate and buddy at Oklahoma. He was drafted by the Giants and became a fan favorite up there
column7: and he also was known for his supermodel ex-wife. After various injuries
column8: “Shep” was on the couch with no team last spring when Mayfield called him to see if he wanted a dance — a last dance? — with the Bucs. He did. Shepard got hurt in training camp and didn’t make the Bucs’ 53-man roster
column9: but he was willing to play for practice squad money and got promoted quickly. Shepard finished with 32 catches for 334 yards with handful of big plays and stupid penalties. The latter drove fans crazy
column10: but there is no denying Shepard is a very solid option as a No. 5(ish) receiver. He’ll compete with Trey Palmer and Todd Bowles-fave Rakim Jarrett for a spot behind Mike Evans
column11: Godwin and Jalen McMillan. Bowles talked about personally scouting receivers at the NFL Scouting Combine
column12: though Joe is dubious after today’s Shepard signing and Godwin’s chatter about hard practice this August. Joe agrees with Kaufman that Mayfield has a very heavy hand in a lot of things on his side of the ball. He should. He’s a young franchise quarterback the Bucs hope has at least another five seasons in Tampa.|2025-03-14 20:55:00|312|42|6|Baker Mayfield|Mayfield makes moves to strengthen Buccaneers' offense for upcoming season.|4|Mixed sentiments regarding Baker Mayfield's performance and draft priorities

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/joe-sure-hopes-haason-reddick-doesnt-forget-the-past/|Sure Hope Haason Reddick Doesn’t Forget The Past|When new Bucs edge rusher (thank you
column2: God!) Haason Reddick took a couple of brisk steps toward the podium at the media studio inside One Buc Palace this morning
column3: he greeted reporters and wore a smile. In Reddick’s mind
column4: he wanted to put the past behind him. Specifically
column5: Reddick didn’t want to discuss being traded from the Eagles to the Jets last year
column7: and a nightmare of a season that didn’t begin until October. “Very bizarre
column8: ” is how Reddick described his 2024 season with a chuckle. That was a line he repeated a couple of times. That was about the extent that he allowed reporters any insight into why the Jets turned out to be a nightmare for him. The Bucs didn’t bring Reddick in to be an afterthought like he was in the New Jersey Swamplands (one sack). Rather
column9: the Bucs brought him to town because he had 50.5 sacks the previous four seasons for the Eagles
column10: Panthers and Cardinals. A couple of times Reddick said he wanted to keep the past in the past and was just focused on the future. Joe hopes Reddick doesn’t put the past behind him. After two years in Arizona
column11: Reddick was labeled a bust because Cardinals coaches thought he could be the next Derrick Brooks instead of a scary pass rusher. In his fourth year in the league
column12: Arizona had a change of heart
column13: moved him back to outside linebacker and allowed Reddick to release the hounds. Reddick responded with 12.5 sacks when he moved back to outside linebacker. Joe also hopes Reddick doesn’t forget how he walked on at Temple. Coming from a disadvantaged home
column14: he overcame a lot of obstacles to eventually win a scholarship at the Philadelphia institution. Joe sure hopes Reddick doesn’t put that past behind him. Because that work ethic is why Reddick will getting paid this year if he lives up to his past history. If Reddick wants to forget the Jets
column15: no problem. Just also remember the good of the past and how that helped mold him into the player he is.|2025-03-14 16:48:00|351|20|6|Haason Reddick|Reddick's past and future in football discussed with optimism and caution.|7|Optimistic reactions to Reddick's addition

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/connections-key-for-haason-reddick/|Connections Key For Haason Reddick|So new Bucs beastly (hopefully) edge rusher Haason Reddick met with Joe and other local media at One Buc Palace today and made a few things very clear. No. 1
column2: Reddick is in Tampa because of his connections with Bucs coaches. In particular
column3: Bucs outside linebackers coach Larry Foote spent two years around Reddick in Arizona
column4: and Foote was a bit of mentor for the Cardinals’ first-round pick. While Reddick was pegged as an inside linebacker by then head coach Bruce Arians (his final season there)
column5: Foote was all over the versatile Reddick to learn how to get to the quarterback. After Foote moved on
column6: the Cardinals finally made Reddick an edge rusher
column7: what he was in college at Temple
column9: Reddick’s smile told a huge story when he was asked today about playing with Vita Vea and Calijah Kancey. And Joe will say a No. 3 message from Reddick is he wanted to play in a place that felt like home. A walk-on at Temple from a very tough southwest New Jersey city named Camden (is the Campbell’s soup factory still there?) Reddick said he’s known all kinds of adversity in his life and it feels routine to him. So his high-profile holdout mess with the Jets last season
column10: after what he called business disagreements with the Eagles
column11: isn’t something that set him back
column12: he said. Reddick said he’s currently 6-1
column13: 245 pounds and ready to the attack-dog violent edge rusher he’s known to be. His greatest strength? Reddick said it’s smarts. He knows how to win at the line of scrimmage. Joe will share more from Reddick later today.|2025-03-14 11:04:00|275|33|5|Haason Reddick|Reddick's connection with Bucs coaches and optimism about future.|8|Positive outlook on team improvements with new acquisitions and defensive strategy adjustments.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""WiscoJoe""

column301: ""post"": ""Until Todd changes his philosophy I will keep harping on his propensity to drop big guys into coverage and have the little guys pass rush.""
column310: ""post"": ""Bucs were top 10 in pressures/sacks last year if I remember correctly. The main issue has been soft coverage. When teams face us they knew we had a blitz-happy HC and guys up front who could get after a QB
column311: so OCs schemed quick passes to wide-open receivers because our DBs were playing 10 yards or more away from the receivers at the snap. Play tighter coverage off the L.O.S. and make the QB hold the ball for a half-second or full-second longer and the sacks will pile up. That\u2019s how so many rookie and young QBs do so well against us. It plays into their hands and lets the OC give his young QB easy completions.""
column320: ""post"": ""Looks like Licht/Bowles are emphasizing the Defense now. YES!!!!!""
